message: The aforementioned problem only seems to happen when I use NERDTree. Vim's own Netrw Directory Listing seems to work fine once the original volume is remounted.

I often edit on a mounted volume over SFTP. On TextMate I was able to open a bunch of files, unmount the volume and mount it back again and continue editing as nothing happened. If I attempt the same with Vim, after disconnecting, the files stay open but it has no idea where the file was. A :file command shows the relative path but a :pwd returns a “E187: Unknown” error. Any thoughts?
Changing the working directory using `cd` to the original one makes all buffers work again, but NERDTree is broken for me too.

Oh, I must have overlooked it. After changing the directory using `cd` everything works (even NERDTree), if I haven't messed with it while in unmounted state. If it doesn't work you can press `Shift+R` in NERDTree to refresh it and it should work again.
Can't say that I've edited very many files over sftp with vim...  I prefer to simply SSH into a box and edit right there in the terminal.  Is that an option for you?

I do almost all of my edits over SFTP. Unmounting while Vim is running messes things up, as you say. If my `pwd` is `/mnt/sshfs/machine/directory` before unmounting and remounting, after that it's `/directory` so Vim can't find the files.
IMO, your best option is to connect on the remote server with ssh and start vim is a screen or tmux session. Any any reason why sftp monted volume would be a better option?
I guess the advantage of ssh mounted volumes would be the ability to edit them with gVIM / MacVim.

I think this is a problem with new fuse inodes or possibly the way vim uses tmp files. If vi compatible mode works then you can dig around and find the rc option(s) that says to use tmp files (or not) and/or how. Does the problem go away if you use :w! /full/path?
vim can edit files over SSH directly: help netrw
@0chris X forwarding FTW. I do this at work :)
@codekoala of course, that too. But then you have gvim installed on your server... hmm....

The advantage of ssh mounted volumes is that you remain on your machine and can do whatever you want easily..  and it's not just about editing files in Vim.. you can open up GIMP to edit an image, etc.
@judofyr netrw and vim's directory listings in tree view in one tab, opening anything I want to edit in new tabs.
